quote: "Non-sororal polygyny tends to be associated with kinship terminology of the bifurcate collateral type"
justification: Polygyny spatially separates lineal relatives, meaning women are surrounded by co-wives and not sisters, and children by half-siblings and not parallel cousins, which prevents merging of lineal kinship terms.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Crow systems should occur more frequency in societies which are avunculocal ..."
justification: Avunculoval residence means married couples move to live with the husband's mother's brother and are spatially closer to maternal kin, meaning there is more pressure to specifically identify maternal kin, and paternal kin can be grouped together. With specific reference to Crow societies, it is likely that this also aligns with matrilateral cross-cousin marriage.
reference: Eyde, D. B., & Postal, P. M. (1961). Avunculocal and Incest: The Development of Unilateral Cross-Cousin Marriage and Crow-Omaha Kinship Systems. American Anthropologist, 63(4), 747–771.

quote: "The tables show a strong correlation between Omaha terms and patrilineal unilineal descent groups and between Crow terms and matrilineal unilineal descent groups"
justification: A matrilineal descent system imposes a higher social status (social differential) on maternal kin, and therefore the need to distinguish maternal kin over paternal. This allows the grouping of paternal kin.
reference: Goody, J. (1970). Cousin Terms. Southwestern Journal of Anthropology, 26(2), 125–142.

quote: "Non-sororal polygyny tends to be associated with kinship terminology of the bifurcate collateral type"
justification: Polygyny spatially separates lineal relatives, meaning women are surrounded by co-wives and not sisters, and children by half-siblings and not parallel cousins, which prevents merging of lineal kinship terms.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "In the presence of patrilocal, matri-local or avunculocal residence, separate terms tend to be applied to relatives of the same generation who are linked to ego through connecting relatives of a different sex."
justification: A unilocal residence rule brings into proximity a group of relatives linked under one line of decent. This rule acts as a social differential to support bifurcation of cousin terms.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Prohibition on cousins vary [in Eskimo-types], but as one might expect, are inevitably bilateral"
justification: If all cousins are unmarriagable, there is no social differential and therefore no need to distinguish them
reference: Fox, R. (1967). Kinship and Marriage: An Anthropological Perspective. Cambridge University Press.

quote: "Prohibition on cousins vary [in Eskimo-types], but as one might expect, are inevitably bilateral"
justification: If all cousins are unmarriagable, there is no social differential and therefore no need to distinguish them
reference: Fox, R. (1967). Kinship and Marriage: An Anthropological Perspective. Cambridge University Press.

quote: "…there is a distinct association of Eskimo terms with bilateral [descent] systems"
justification: When terms differentiate between full siblings and cousins when they are socially differentiated (in this case it is proposed to reflect direct patterns of inheritance).
reference: Goody, J. (1970). Cousin Terms. Southwestern Journal of Anthropology, 26(2), 125–142.

quote: "The following variables are dependent upon diverging devolution (transmission of property to both males and females): greater control of women's' marriage (prohibition of premarital sex, endogamy, father's brother's daughter marriage, monogamy, alternative residence) and by extension Eskimo kinship terminology which isolates the sibling group form "cousins""
justification: When there is a social focus on the monogamous nuclear family, there is a need to distinguish children and siblings from other closely related nuclear families.
reference: Goody, J., Irving, B., & Tahany, N. (1970). Causal Inferences Concerning Inheritance and Property. Human Relations, 24, 295–314.

quote: "Neolocal residence tends to be associated with kinship terminology of the lineal type."
justification: Neo-local residence results in the spatial seperation of lineal relatives from all colateral relative, and emphasises the residential group
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "In the absence of clans and polygamous and extended families, the isolated nuclear family tends to be associated with kinship terminology of the lineal type."
justification: The isolation of the nuclear family operates as a social differenetial and favours separate terms for the lineal and colateral kin.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Hawaiian [kin] terms … are associated with the prohibition on [cross] cousin marriage"
justification: If all cousins are unmarriagable, there is no social differential and therefore no need to distinguish them
reference: Goody, J. (1970). Cousin Terms. Southwestern Journal of Anthropology, 26(2), 125–142.

quote: "Hawaiian [kin] terms … are associated with the prohibition on [cross] cousin marriage"
justification: If all cousins are unmarriagable, there is no social differential and therefore no need to distinguish them
reference: Goody, J. (1970). Cousin Terms. Southwestern Journal of Anthropology, 26(2), 125–142.

quote: "Bilateral kindreds tend to be associated with kinship terminology of the generation type"
justification: If there is no social differential between maternal or paternal relatives,  nor is there a pressure to distinguish nuclear family from other kin, then there is no pressure to linguistically distinguish siblings and cousins, or parents, and parent's siblings.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "The several types of extended family … depend upon the prevailing rule of residence and exert the influences upon kinship nomenclature already set forth  in Theorems 6 and 11"
justification: Extended families increase social participation and interdependence within society and there fore emphasise the effect of bilineal descent.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Bilocal residence tends to be associated with kinship terminology of the generation type"
justification: Bilineal decent brings together some lineal kin, and some colateral kin, some through men and some though women. All these groups combined are then all overridden and individuals are treated equally.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Iroquois [kin] terms … are associated with preferred cross-cousin marriage"
justification: If cousin marriage is allowed (or preferred) in some but not all cousins, there is a pressure to linguistically distinguish those who are marriagable from those who are not.
reference: Goody, J. (1970). Cousin Terms. Southwestern Journal of Anthropology, 26(2), 125–142.

quote: "Iroquois [kin] terms … are associated with preferred cross-cousin marriage"
justification: If cousin marriage is allowed (or preferred) in some but not all cousins, there is a pressure to linguistically distinguish those who are marriagable from those who are not.
reference: Goody, J. (1970). Cousin Terms. Southwestern Journal of Anthropology, 26(2), 125–142.

quote: "In the presence of exogamous matrilineal or patrilineal lineages, sibs, phratries, or moieties, terms for lineal relatives tend to be extended, within the same sex and generation, to collateral kinsmen who would be affiliated with them under either unilinear rules of descent."
justification: Kin that are members of the same exogamous unilinear group are socially equalized with colateral kin, and are therefore terms are merged.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Non-sororal polygyny tends to be associated with kinship terminology of the bifurcate collateral type"
justification: Polygyny spatially separates lineal relatives, meaning women are surrounded by co-wives and not sisters, and children by half-siblings and not parallel cousins, which prevents merging of lineal kinship terms.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Matrilocal and avunculocal residence tend to be associated with kinship terminology of the bifurcate merging type"
justification: Avunculocal residences aligns relatives so that the distinction of collaterality is minimized and there is a tendence to extend kinship terms from lineal to collateral co-residing relatives.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Non-sororal polygyny tends to be associated with kinship terminology of the bifurcate collateral type"
justification: Polygyny spatially separates lineal relatives, meaning women are surrounded by co-wives and not sisters, and children by half-siblings and not parallel cousins, which prevents merging of lineal kinship terms. This results in different terms for parent's opposite sex sibling terms.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "The classic but erroneous anthropological view concerning the nature of the 'Iroquois type' of kinship system … is that this kind of system classifies kin by membership in unilineal descent groups"
reference: Lounsbury, F. G. (1964). The structural analysis of kinship semantics. Mouton.

quote: "In the presence of patrilocal, matri-local or avunculocal residence, separate terms tend to be applied to relatives of the same generation who are linked to ego through connecting relatives of a different sex."
justification: A uni-local residence rule brings into proximity a group of relatives linked under one line of decent. This rule acts as a social differential to support bifurcation of cousin terms.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Non-sororal polygyny tends to be associated with kinship terminology of the bifurcate collateral type"
justification: Polygyny spatially separates lineal relatives, meaning women are surrounded by co-wives and not sisters, and children by half-siblings and not parallel cousins, which prevents merging of lineal kinship terms. This results in different terms for parent's opposite sex sibling terms.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "Matrilocal and avunculocal residence tend to be associated with kinship terminology of the bifurcate merging type"
justification: Avunculocal residences aligns relatives so that the distinction of collaterality is minimized and there is a tendence to extend kinship terms from lineal to collateral co-residing relatives.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

quote: "The tables show a strong correlation between Omaha terms and patrilineal unilineal descent groups and between Crow terms and matrilineal unilineal descent groups"
justification: Patrilineal descent acts as a social differential between maternal and paternal kin, allowing more terminological distinction between patrilineal relatives, and grouping of matrilineal relatives.
reference: Goody, J. (1970). Cousin Terms. Southwestern Journal of Anthropology, 26(2), 125–142.

quote: "Non-sororal polygyny tends to be associated with kinship terminology of the bifurcate collateral type"
justification: Polygyny spatially separates lineal relatives, meaning women are surrounded by co-wives and not sisters, and children by half-siblings and not parallel cousins, which prevents merging of lineal kinship terms. This results in different terms for parent's opposite sex sibling terms.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.

justification: A uni-local residence rule brings into proximity a group of relatives linked under one line of decent. This rule acts as a social differential to support bifurcation of cousin terms.
reference: Murdock, G. P. (1949). Social structure (Vol. xvii). Oxford, England: Macmillan.
